Title: Dojo 

Genre: Third person Fighting game 

Design Pillars: Combat, Training, Story, Linear Map 

Features: Environments destructible, Textures Hand-Painted

 Mechanics Summary:

 Fight against single or multiple enemies using different fighting techniques; Simple Hit (punch, kick, etc. ), Area Hit (like energy hit), Destructible Environment (hitting a stone the enemies take damage).There are Masters of Martial Arts(each one with a different combat style) where you can learn/training a new fighting technique and build new attack patterns. Every “Dojo” imposes you to have respected adversary fighting or not, then you need a behavioral bar positive or negative depending on master. 

Story: 

The story develops in 4 acts: 1° act_ the Intro (Game Demo) where the player take a brutal hit and lose the memory, through the road map you come to know, that during the night there is a tournament to elect the new henchman of boss and you are the favorite of your boss's village. At the end of this road waiting for you there is your antagonist's in the tournament and you loose. 2° act_ Bandit of the village by the boss, you arrive to a small village where you come to know a first Master, he teach/training you a new Martial Art. When you stabilize there, the antagonist comes with other enemies to take resource from the village, you come to know this was your old life. The master ordinate you to go fare, because you don't are prepare to combat against this enemy and tell you about a monastery. 3° act_ You run to the monastery, know the Shaolin Master and he tells you how to use the KI for new attacks. When you are ready, you return to the village, you come to know that enemies killed the old master because he helped you. 4° act_ You return at the boss village to face up to antagonist and boss. 

 Interface: Player interact whit game only with the Joystick

Attacks: The attacks will never be detected, it will be up to the player to discover them, trying various key combinations, even the various masters will suggest the new move to learn but not how to perform it.
